Jazelle Hunt is a student at Howard University in Washington D.C., and Jarvis McInnis attends Tougaloo College in Mississippi.
Both teens have devoted years of service to the Boys and Girls Clubs of America, and both are former youth of the year winners.
We turn to these outstanding young people for their perspectives on the findings.
I started by asking Jarvis what he thought was the most the important finding in the survey?
We, as youth, have goals and dreams, but we feel that we aren't able to realize those opportunities; the hopes outweigh the opportunities in America.
I thought that was very shocking.
I thought that that was something that may have been--to see the sentiment--was the same around the country was quite interesting.
Jazelle, what's interesting, and Dr. Poussaint and I talked about it, is the idea that there is still this need--often for young people--to reach out to parent and mentors.

When you talk with young people--and even amongst your intimate circle, your friends--do you feel the sense that the older generation is looking to you and understanding some of what you're going through?
The survey does show that while we value our parents and our leaders to the fullest extent, it oftentimes seems, though, there is a communication gap.

And a lot of times all we're looking is just--for our parents, and the people that are older than us, looking out for us--we just would like them to listen to us more and be more open to what we're saying.
Jazelle, how much do you believe the idea of what the expectation is for young people and the reality is--the survey talks about this gap.
How much do you and your friends feel that there is this real want to do well in school, to get a good job, to live the American dream--and then the real ability to do so?
There's definitely this great desire to be successful, and to have an education, and all those great things that the survey talks about.
But at the same time, it often seems as though we're not sure if those things are attainable to us.
Not because perhaps they're not there--or it just seems as though we're not sure of the way.
We need someone to help us with that.
Jarvis, let me ask you, in terms of the responses you looked over, the numbers--were you surprised at any of the numbers that you saw.
Often, and I don't mean just teenagers, but people, will take a poll a they'll tell you what they think you want to hear.
Do you think that that's true in some the responses here?
Absolutely, not.
I found that I agreed with so many of the results there.
So I really think that our youth were very honest and they gave their honest opinions.
What about, Jarvis, leadership from your peers?
Both you and Jazelle are young people striving, and involved, and doing a lot.
We hear so often, particularly among males, that that is sometimes looked down on.
How have you been dealt with by peers with your activities and all of what you have attained?
I think, in the beginning, some people may not totally understand.
But I've actually have been very blessed and very fortunate, in that I've been accepted very well amongst my peers.
But I also have the attitude to where I'm going to do what it takes to get to where I want to be, no matter how anyone else feels about it.
I'm very independent, and I'm very driven.
We should note that you were elected student body president.

I was always the kid in school who, even though I may surround myself with the smart persons or the-you know, we have these different classes in high school or these different groups--I kind of tried to hang out and speak to everyone, to show everyone that I'm a down to earth person.
And just like I'm all about the books, I'm also about having fun.
And I guess they were able to see that in me, and I've taken that same method to college.

Jazelle, now, for young women it is often a bit different.
The idea of achievement is often fostered among the group.

Nuristani says Taliban fighters control most of her province.
The insurgents vehemently oppose women being involved in politics and have vowed to disrupt the elections.
Nuristani says that as a result, none of the four female candidates running for the provincial council is permitted by their families to go out and campaign.
Nor do their male relatives allow them to use photos of themselves on campaign posters.
Back in Kabul, where Afghan and international forces have tightened security in advance of the polls, women candidates have an easier time reaching out to voters.
Farida Bayat is one of 63 women running for the nine provincial council seats that are set aside for her sex.
(Foreign language spoken)
The 37-year-old says she's campaigned at schools, local organizations and even a neighborhood mosque.
Her face is visible on thousands of campaign fliers.
She doesn't wear the head-to-toe burqa frequently worn by women in Afghanistan.
But per Islamic tradition, her hair is covered by a loose-fitting scarf.
(Through Translator) I'm determined to see future generations of girls like my daughter gain confidence by seeing me and other women taking these steps.
Women are half the population of this country and should be taking part in politics and everything else.
Not everyone agrees.
Bayat says a man called her two weeks ago to deliver a death threat because she's a woman running for office.
She's also gotten other harassing phone calls.
Her husband, Lutfallah, says he fears for her safety and has asked her not to travel outside of the capital.
(Through Translator) Sure I'm frightened, because some people are just ignorant and violent.
They think that being Muslim means that their women must stay at home.
They don't understand that women should work and be in the government.
This is what has kept our country from advancing.
In a June report, Afghanistan's Independent Human Rights Commission said it had received 15 formal complaints from women candidates about intimidation.

And even though there have been no reports of violence against women running for office so far, the Ministry of Interior was concerned enough to start assigning a policeman to any female provincial candidate who requested one.
Sima Samar, who chairs the human rights commission, says it's not just Taliban militants who are impeding women in this election.
She says female candidates are also stifled by chauvinistic traditions and a lack of campaign funds.
She also accuses the country's male presidential candidates of setting a poor example for other Afghan men.
She says women are almost invisible in their campaigns, even at their rallies.
You see a small group of people in one corner, but the rest are all men.
And this is sad.
This shows the reality in this country.
Samar says it's not only women candidates who are suffering.
Fear of violence also makes potential women voters vulnerable to election fraud.
In May, local election watchdogs reported suspicious voter registration trends in several eastern provinces, like in Logar, where a whopping 72 percent of new voters signing up were said to be women.
Many Afghans here, like Wadir Safi, a political analyst who teaches law at Kabul University, fear women's voter cards will be sold to the highest bidder.
Safi says such fraud is hard to prevent, given that women's movements are so restricted.
They cannot come out of their houses.
That's why a person is coming to the commission there, and say I'm representing 300 houses, for example.
Give me so many cards.
In every house, there are 20 ladies, and they have given (unintelligible).
They have paid them money to collect such cards, and it goes to the ballot box of one candidate.
But Afghan election officials insist that on election day, there only be one vote per person.
They say men will not be allowed to cast ballots for their female relatives.
The officials add that after Afghan voters cast their ballots, their fingers will be stained with an indelible ink that can't be removed for several days.
